repnme.cdata!:
Mali, Mauritania & Senegal Regional
            Hydropower Development Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Mali, Mauritania
            & Senegal Regional Hydropower Development Project is
            rated satisfactory. As a result of achieving its physical
            and its core development objectives, albeit with
            considerable delays, the RKDP has enabled the provision of
            low-cost hydroelectricity to the three countries, and has
            improved access as well as the reliability and quality of
            power supplies. The project also succeeded in involving a
            private operator and initiated pilot programs to benefit
            rural populations as well as mitigate the negative
            environmental and health impacts of the dam. At the design
            and preparation stage, good technical preparation is
            essential if delays and cost increases are to be avoided.
            Procurement activities related to the key components should
            be as advanced as feasible prior to negotiations, in order
            to allow sufficient time for project management  to take any
            necessary corrective measures and avoid delays.
            Harmonization of donor procedures, particularly on
            procurement, should be established prior to implementation.
            Financing and disbursement procures should also  be
            harmonized to achieve better coordination among co-lenders
            in the processing of payments. Mitigation of environmental
            impacts should be appropriately covenanted in the legal
            documents, and time-bound with provisions for remedial
            actions by International Development Associations (IDAs).

7345335.owner: Office of the Regional Vice Pres (AFRVP),Energy Practice 1 (AFTG1)
7345335.trustfund:
TF020195-PHRD-POWER DEVELOPMENT PROJ.,TF023976-FAC CONSULTANT TRUST FUND (USD A/C),TF035840-AFRICA REGION - REGIONAL
            HYDROPOWER PROJECT,UN009960-PREP ASST FOR IRRIGATION & DRAINAGE

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings convey a satisfactory project
            outcome, likely sustainability, substantial institutional
            development impacts, and satisfactory performances by the
            Bank and Borrower. Several lessons of experience were drawn
            from this project, some are as follows. Better technical
            preparation, especially concerning the studies leading to
            the construction of the power plant, the transmission lines,
            and the dispatch center should have been foreseen in the
            project design. Moreover, detailed designs/studies should
            have been completed prior to the launching of the bidding
            process (a responsibility left to the contractor who
            produced detailed designs during contract execution). This
            would have helped limit cost increases due to contract
            addendums, and avoid uncontrolled cost overruns for the
            Borrower. In addition, there is need for better financing
            harmonization: project implementation needed better and
            timely coordination among co-lenders on issues involving
            procurement and processing of payments, in light of the
            project's complex financing arrangements, which
            undermined project execution. Furthermore, it would have
            been useful to establish Special Accounts for the Mauritania
            and Senegal Credits, which would have reduced work slowdown
            due to delays in payment. Bank financing should have been
            conditional to the successful implementation of an
            Environmental Assessment, because delays in implementing the
            Water Charter and the resulting Manantali Reservoir
            Management Program threatened to damage the environment, and
            undermine the resettlement of affected populations. Both of
            these issues could have been negotiated prior to both plant
            and transmission systems construction. Nonetheless, the
            project stimulated a series of actions in the region:
            Cooperation between Mali, Mauritania and Senegal, resulting
            in the creation of an institutional framework, thus
            harmonizing national planning and legal frameworks to
            promote development, trade and labor flows. It is suggested
            member states need to create the conditions to stimulate
            investment (public and private).

694321.trustfund:
TF023976-FAC CONSULTANT TRUST FUND (USD A/C),TF035840-AFRICA REGION - REGIONAL

repnme.cdata!:
Mali, Mauritania & Senegal - Regional
            Hydropower Development Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Regional Hydropower Development
            Project's main objectives are to: (i) reduce the
            long-term cost of electricity supply to the 3 countries;
            (ii) contribute to meeting debt service associated with the
            building of the Manantali dam; (iii) contribute to
            increasing the efficiency and reliability of power systems;
            (iv) establish an effective organization to construct and
            operate the project facilities and to mitigate environment
            and health impacts of the projects and the Manantali dam;
            (v) promote competitive private sector participation; and
            (vi) support the traditional agricultural sector downstream
            through the rational management of the Manantali reservoir.
            The project's components are as follows: 1) power
            station including civil works, electromechanical equipment,
            step-up substation, and reinforcement works; 2) transmission
            system comprising transmission lines and a dispatching
            center; 3) construction supervision; 4) institutional
            strengthening including studies, training, procurement of
            equipment and other support; and 5) Project Preparation
            Facility Advance refinancing.

repnme.cdata!:
Mali, Mauritania, et Senegal - Projet
            Energie Manantali - evaluation environnementale

abstracts.cdata!:
This report presents an environmental
            assessment on the implementation of the Regional Hydropower
            Development Project in Mali, Mauritania, and Senegal.
            Harmful and negative impacts due to the implementation of
            the project have been identified, covering biodiversity, as
            well as socio-economic aspects. The lack of early
            consultations with the affected population as of the
            construction of the reservoir in 1988, has created a
            negative approach on the socio-economic front. Furthermore,
            due to flooding and water contamination, endemic diseases
            and malnutrition have affected the population health.
            Mitigation measures have been taken for biodiversity
            protection, such as diverting power lines from the protected
            zones. Nevertheless, the social problems affecting an
            essentially rural population need to be addressed, which
            legislation has, thus far, failed to accomplish. The
            creation of local coordination committees with strong
            representation rights is suggested, to establish the link
            with national governments in order to evaluate health and
            compensation rights, including supplementary retraining and
            monitoring management efficiency. An annex to this report
            will follow covering the environmental plan on the
            development of a sustainable reservoir management system for
            the Manantali Power Project.

Mali, Mauritania, et Senegal - Projet
            Energie Manantali - evaluation environnementale
